questions.question_text:
A company uses Dynamics 365 for Sales.
You create a new quote and associate an opportunity to the quote.
You need to display all your items from the opportunity in the quote.
What should you do?

choices.B: Select Get Products from the command bar in the Quote entity
choices.C: Select Add Line Items on the Opportunity entity
choices.D: Select Recalculate from the command bar on the Opportunity entity

discussion.content:
B is correct answer.

questions.question_text:
An organization attends a tradeshow and identifies several leads.
One specific lead wants to make a purchase in the next week.
You need to create an invoice.
At which stage can you create the invoice?

discussion.content:
Are you all agree?
In this way someone must manually create the Account and starting the process from the Order we also loss any relationship with the Lead, this could be a problem analyzing the revenue from the tradeshow.
Couldn't be better start the process from the biginning?
Create a Lead->Qualify(This step create Account and Opportunity)->Create a Quote->Create the Order->Create the Invoice.
I know, It's a lot of steps, but most of then are automatically done.
I'm not sure, It's only a question...

comments.content: You're right, but in the end also you affirm that you create the invoice from the Order, so stop overthinking, Order is the right answer

The correct answer is Order because you can't create directly from any of the listed entities. Yes, invoice can be created from scratch at any stage of the process by manually going into Invoice entity and creating new. But from a process perspective, the only place you can create it is from the Order record. Even though you can link an invoice to an Opportunity directly but this must be done from scratch, i.e. Create new Invoice from scratch, add Opportunity lookup

comments.content: Your A and B are contradictory. In both scenario, you are talking about updating Parent Product Family which can be achieved by unpublish the Product Family (if its already published).

The question is as bit stupid. But the answer is correct, so A. If you go through the answers it makes sense:
A. Add a new product family to an existing product family - correct you can do that, because you will set the existing Product family as parent
B. Delete the existing price list and create a new one - you should never delete existing price list which was used on Opprtunity
C. Create a unit group for use with the product family - Creating new Unit group is useless when you need a new Product family
D. Add a parent product family to an existing product family - adding parent Product family to existing Product family is not possible because once you created it the field is locked

questions.question_text:
You are a Dynamics 365 system customizer. You create a price list with related products. Sales team members use the list to generate opportunities, quotes, and orders.
You need to create a product family.
What should you do?

choices.C: Create a unit group for use with the product family
choices.B: Delete the existing price list and create a new one
choices.D: Add a parent product family to an existing product family
choices.A: Add a new product family to an existing product family

questions.question_text:
You are creating orders from quotes in Dynamics 365.
In some circumstances, customers no longer require an order. In other circumstances, your company delivers the order.
You need to ensure that closed orders use existing functionality to reflect the circumstances.
Which two methods of closing an order are available out of the box? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content: A and D are correct answers

Correct answer.
"You close an order by either fulfilling the order or canceling the order. Products or services that are shipped are fulfilled. You should cancel orders for any products or services that are not shipped."
A and D are correct answers
4 and 2 - "When your quote is ready to send to your customer, on the command bar, select Activate Quote."

Correct
"When your quote is ready to send to your customer, on the command bar, select Activate Quote."

comments.content: Yes.. verified same in trial. we can send quote without activating itself

discussion.content: 4 and 1. 4 because the other 3 are incorrect. 1 because Export to Pdf button appears after the quote is saved. You can still export to pdf and send the quote when quote is in draft mode.

"An administrative assistant is unable to access the function to edit a quote "
So the answer is to assign to someone who can't do it? #Genius

comments.content: first 3 options are not correct, assigning the quote is the only possible solution assuming Admin Assistant is not able to edit it bcoz Quote is not assigned to him and he is only having user level edit access.

discussion.content: The "Print Quote for Customer" will only be missing when the quote is not saved. I just verified.

comments.content:
Yep, 4 and 1. 
4 is the best answer out of a bad lot for the first question, as you can't "edit" a Quote once Activated, can only Revise it
1 is best answer to second question. If a user can't "send to customer" it means the Export to PDF button isn't enabled, which means the Quote isn't saved. Once saved, button is enabled, doesn't matter whether Activated or not
Even that is not true, as soon as you click on create Quote button, quote id is generated (means quote is created) and the Export to PDF button gets enabled (as works as expected).
